description.text:
I've used TinkerCAD to create a periodic table with the 3D printer. Each tile includes the elements symbol, atomic number, and mass number.

Using these in the classroom is ideal. You can print specific elements a unique color plastic to indicate (periodic families, state of matter, classification of matter, etc).

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2
TinkerCAD

1) Grab Bag of Elements: When you are choosing groups or lab partners, each student can grab an element from the bag. Then based on the content, students will be asked to go to specific groups.
Ex: If your element have the 3 valance electrons, go to lab station #3
Ex: If your element is in the Alkali Metal Family, go to lab station #1 2) Each student could be given a set of all the elements. Have the students organize the elements according to:
--- state of matter (solids/liquids/gases)
--- classification of matter (metals, metalloids, nonmetals)
--- periodic family
--- facts about the elements discovery (year, nation, scientist) 3) These tiles could be used to enrich lessons about
--- electron configuration
--- chemical bonding
--- molar mass 4) Special Education
--- using these tiles in the special education classroom can make learning chemistry easier. It is a visual way of helping students learn how to calculate molar mass for any chemical formula. It is a hands-on tool for learning about how the periodic table is organized.
I needed a straight filament guide that could attach to a 40mm T rail, so I cobbled this together. Sharing in case it could be of use to someone else.

comments.text: And 40mm diam filament  :-). These filament guides are such fun !

title: Watch Case for 6498 Manual Wind Movement

description.text: A 44mm diameter watch case, sized for a 6497 or 6498 large caliber manual wind movement, and a large watch crown. Print out case and crown, purchase movement, mounting parts, top/bottom crystal, and then assemble your own horological masterpiece!

You can use this case and crown to make your own watch with a
large pocket watch caliber manual wind movement. You will need to print: -- Watch case
-- Watch crown You will need to buy: -- a 6498 or 6497 manual wind movement
(you can buy these here [http://www.siswatch727.com/showroom/model/T0165/templateProductDetails.do?ParentId=1240797174312004223Â¤tPage=1&editCurrentLanguage=1239717806671017347&webId=1239717806671017346&productId=1242292509609011170]or elsewhere on ebay.
They range from 35 USD for Chinese to 390 USD
for an ETA swiss movement. -- Crystal for front and back, with compression gasket
(both are 40mm diameter, compression gasket is 40.5mm) -- Screw bars for 26mm lugs (strap width is 24mm, but lugs
are extra wide). You will need to clean drill the lugs for these,
the diameter of the hole will vary slightly depending on print settings (appx 3.00 USD) -- A 24mm watch strap with buckle (will come with spring bars
, but these are not suitable for this case) appx 5-30 USD -- Movement mounting plates with screws (appx 3.00 USD) to secure the movement in place -- A dial and hands-- you can find these from a watch supplier
like otto frei or make your own. I will be posting printable
hands and dials to follow, these are still a work in progress. You should probably print this with exterior support or the
lugs will sag. How you assemble: 1) Once you have printed and cleaned it up, you can install
the watch movement from the top of the watch. Make sure the
watch is in winding position (or keyless works will fall out),
and that you take the hour wheel and hour wheel gasket off,
or they will fall out as well while working. 2) The crown stem needs to , be fit with the crown you choose,
the stem can be trimmed and sanded with wire cutters. Then
install the crown by screwing in, and setting with small amount
of glue if you wish. 3) Secure the movement in place with movement mounting
plates/tabs. There are tab slots in the model, which you
will need to clean up crisp to put the tabs in place. 4) Install the dial, and fix to the movement bottom plate,
or if the dial has feet (sized for a 6497/8 movement),
slide the feet into holes in the movement bottom plate and
fix with mounting screws. 5) Install hands (center hour and min, and small seconds (
location of seconds depends on movement purchased-- the
6497 will have no seconds hand, or small seconds at 9
oclock position-- the 6498 will have small seconds hand
at 6 oclock position) 6) Install crystal gasket, and lay crystal in place. The crystal should not need to be glued, it will snap in place with the gasket. Assembling the watch is not the easiest thing, and there
are tricky steps, but all it really requires is patience,
and a proper set of jewlers screwdrivers. If you run into
problems contact me, or you can find many watch assembly
guides on the net. Happy Printing!

title: Binocular Camera Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Just an experiment to see if I can photograph closeup photos of the moon through my binoculars. The binoculars are Celestron Skymaster.

My Olympus TG-4 has a removable front ring which accessories can be attached to. After a lot of prototyping I successfully managed to get the dimensions correct.

The camera front ring attaches to the binocular eyepiece mount using magnets. Magnets are 7mm diameter and 3mm thick.

Initial test results are not as sharp as I was expecting. However, this blur may be due to the camera's internal image stabilisation causing problems. Due to poor weather recently, I haven't had a chance to try again with image stabilisation turned off.

Just putting this project up on Thingiverse as someone might want to use the ring mount for another project.

Project files are available at Onshape.

Object was printed in PETG with only 1 perimeter.

The binocular eyepiece color uses an M3 screw and nut to clamp around the eyepiece. I used my M3 nut knob design for the thumbscrew.

description.text: This is a shorter RollCage for Axial 90056,let you Axial car look nice and can carry a spare wheel，have fun!

This is a 6" diameter fully customizable Geometry manipulative that can be useful in the teaching and learning about the properties of angles, inscribed angles, central angles, arc lengths, and arc measures. Use with a rubber band or two to discover the relationship between inscribed and central angles . Holes for small nails are equally spaced around the circumference along with one in the center. An STL file of a 6" disk that printed well is also included if you don't want to mess with the customizer.

If planning on using this to complement lessons on the subject, print a classroom set so each student can explore, or at least print enough so that each table group can share one.

Additional materials needed:

rubber bands
small nails ( i used some 5/8" nails I had in my workshop with 0.8mm holes) to tap into holes
hammer

If you like this, check out my other objects, including the non-customizable version of this manipulative at: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2179477.

Also, If you want a modification to this design, let me know in the comments and I'll see what I can do.

Updated 3/19/17 - A new version was modeled in Inventor (see the Version 4 STL file, not added to Customizer file yet) that has 24 central angles (15 degrees each) around the whole circle, along with 12 inscribed angles radiating 180 degrees from a single point on the circumference (7.5 degrees each). The intent is to better show the relationship between central angles and inscribed angles.
CCSS

Manipulative for use while teaching Geometry students about inscribed/central angles, arc lengths/measures, sector areas, and more This manipulative is a resource that helps teach to the following Common Core standard: CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.HSG.C.A.2
Identify and describe relationships among inscribed angles, radii, and chords. Include the relationship between central, inscribed, and circumscribed angles; inscribed angles on a diameter are right angles; the radius of a circle is perpendicular to the tangent where the radius intersects the circle.

Pass out these inscribed angle manipulatives after teaching students about the relationships between inscribed and central angles. allow students to explore relationships between radii, arc measure, and angles.

One manipulative per person or table group To assemble each manipulative yo u will need the following: -one printed disk
  • enough nails to fill all the holes. Short nails are preferred with diameter approximately the same as hole diameter, tight fit good to keep nails secure.
  • several rubber bands.

description.text: Use this threaded ring to join two bottles together to transfer the remaining shampoo etc. from a used-up bottle to a new bottle. The threads match most bathroom use bottles. There is a collar inside to seal the bottles. I used it before I added the collar and didn't have any leaks but with the collar it should be better.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I always print a brim with 3 outlines 2 layers to make sure the head is running smooth. I make it 2 layers so it is easier to remove from the bed. I print on clean PEI with ABS bed 110 head 230.

I designed it in OnShape. I measured the thread pitch and size with a micrometer and ran a couple of prototypes to get the diameter right to screw it on the bottle. I added the collar on the inside with a bevel to seal against the top of the bottle. I don't know if the collar is really needed. To get the knurled surface I created a helix of 1/4 turn and created a new surface along the helix. Then I did circular copy to get the right number of elements around the cylinder. Then I did a mirror copy of all of those elements to get the knurled pattern then I did a Boolean subtract.

description.text: As students begin to learn what a plant needs to grow, it is helpful for them to have a model to watch. This activity begins with students sprouting their own seeds and then planting them in different mediums.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No
NGSS
As students begin this lesson, have them think about the needs of plants and the needs of seeds.  Do they both need the same thing?  Is there a way that you can help you plant grow larger? Stronger?

Root Viewer and Sprouting In this activity, students make a root viewer and check on how the roots are growing each day for four days. If a weekend falls during the time when students are checking on the root growth, students will have to take their root viewers home and do the daily observation as homework. Lay CD Case with the hinge at the top.
Put a piece of masking tape at the top corner with your name and date and an arrow pointing up
Open your case and put a piece of damp paper towel inside
Place 5 radish seeds on the paper towel (in two rows)
Close your CD case and make sure to leave it with the arrow pointing up.
In the classroom, you can stack all the CDs together in a large ziplock bag or plastic box. Seeds do not need light to sprout and grow roots. Make sure the masking tape arrows on the CD cases are all pointing in the same direction. Temperature will affect the speed of root growth. In a warm room, the root will be about an inch long on day 3 (the day students are told to turn the root viewer). If your room is cool, the roots may need another day to grow. Alternate version of activity If for some reason you can’t get enough CD cases for your class, you can make a root viewer with a bean in a ziplock bag as a class demonstration. Use these instructions from the Chicago Botanical Garden. This classroom demo will take longer, since beans grow more slowly than radishes. Potting your plants After your seeds have sprouted, talk with students about what they think the sprouts need to survive and to thrive. A good scientist knows that if you add a variable, you need to make sure the rest of the experiment stays the same (constant). Using the preprinted flower mounts, add different planting mediums into the pots. Suggested mediums are vermiculite, potting soil, sand, gel beads. If you have printed enough of the pots, you can put some in the sun and some not in the sun as well for an added comparison. Once the plants have been potted, assemble the planter and mount it on the wall. After students make predictions on which plants will grow the best, the wait begins. Have students track the growth/successes/failures of the plants for a few weeks and then compare their final results to what they had predicted.

Sprouting Seeds and Viewing the Roots a CD case. Ask each student to bring an empty CD case from home or buy some at an office supply store or Amazon.
5 radish seeds. A 3-gram seed packet from your local garden/hardware store or Amazon contains about 240 seeds.
a pencil
a small piece of masking tape
a plastic sandwich bag (to hold the CD case)
a wet paper towel
a Root Viewer Worksheet Potting the Plants Different potting mediums for each pot - vermiculite, get beads, potting soil, sand, etc. Previously printed pots and hangers previously sprouted plants water
Each phase of this lesson could be completed individually or in succession.  The first section is 1-2 weeks.  The 2nd part is 3 weeks.
Make sure to preprint the pots/hangers.

title: Titan idler arm with grooved bearing

description.text:
I was sick of my Titan flattening the filament when I cranked up the idler tension. This was causing jams in my hotend.

This part replaces the idler arm on an E3D Titan extruder, and allows you to use a grooved bearing – which doesn't flatten the filament when you tighten up the tension.

Update Apr 5, 2017 - Moved the filament feed tube by 1.3mm to line up better with the groove in the bearing.

You will need:

  • This part, printed in PETG.
  • A 4mm grub screw (I made one from an M4 bolt, it's very easy with a dremel)
  • A grooved idler bearing from an MK8 style extruder
  • A small length of PTFE tubing.

Drill out the large hole to 13/64". Yes, 5mm is too small. Yes, 5.5mm is too big.

Insert the bearing, and screw the grub screw into the idler to locate it.

Push the PTFE tubing into the top of the idler. It should be a tight friction fit. You may need to chamfer the end to make it slide down better.

Now install on your Titan. Ensure that your stepper motor current is set low enough that the motor doesn't get hot. If the motor gets hot then the idler can deform. The gearing on the Titan means that you can set the current quite low, compared to a direct drive.

Enjoy fewer jams!

comments.text:
It's a true DIY project. You can get it to work with the parts provided with the kit, if they aren't broken. Some of mine were...
The kits seem to have a lot of variation so you might get tight parts or loose parts. Just assemble it as best as you can. Make sure the Y and Z axis are loose enough to move freely but tight enough that they are not sloppy. The first thing you should print is a better shroud with a parts cooling fan. There are tons of them on Thingiverse. Then start printing replacement parts for the acrylics. They are good to have because the acrylics break easily when you over tighten them and you will over tighten them...
I watched a video the other day were the guy was really unimpressed with the kit but then printed a near perfect Benchy with it. I think that sums up the X3 really well.

description.text:
Kitchenaid / Whirlpool dishwasher doors are known for unlatching mid cycle. I made this to prevent mine from unintentionally opening and so far it has done the job well.

It slips under the counter nosing edge. If yours doesn't have the edge it could be modified to work with any profile.

Update, I originally used PLA, it lasted for a while but eventually the dishwasher heat deformed it. I made a new one with PLA/PHA, it lasted a bit longer but eventually failed. I was going to do a metal reinforced version but decided to remove the hinges and see if there was an issue. The hinge was bent so that the edges where no longer parallel. I put it in a vise and made it parallel again...seems to have fixed the latching issues.

Hope that helps anyone with the same issues:)
Printed in Pairs, this allows you to create an adjustable mechanism that can lock together, like an elbow

Begleri - a fun and simple skill toy. If you don't know what begleri is, go to YouTube.

These are 24mm round with a little added to create a recessed center for a p16 o-ring. The o-ring makes them not so 'clanky'. Each 'bead' has (2) 5/16" nuts for weight. 1 in each top and bottom. After inserting the nuts, I used a threaded rod and tapped them in with a hammer - the top and bottom are to be glued together. The larger hole is the bottom to allow for the paracord knot. The picture shows 245 paracord. The pair (2 top, 2 bottom, 4 nuts, 2 o-rings and paracord) fully assembled and strung were 34 grams total.

All the parts in different stages of assemble are shown in the picture.

remixed_from.author: supasorn
remixed_from.title: Dual Blower/Radial Fan Duct Mount (Tevo Tarantula)

title: Tevo Tarantula ultimate dual turbo fan ducts

description.text:
This is a remix of the wonderful design from Supasorn. One issue I had with the original was that it was too flimsy and the fans kept falling out so I added some extrusions that clamp the sides of the fan and added just a bit of rigidity in the frontbar where the bolts go in, but not too much for the bolts current length like some other designs. also I often push the x axis side to side during leveling so it helps to have a sturdy fan mount/ duct. I tried to keep additional weight to just a gram and a half or so. and this fan is a Must have for your new tarantula.

Obviously I could have just glued the fans in.. but Its nice to be able to easily install and uninstall the fans from the duct, without needing gluing/ ungluing, as they are not needed for ABS plastic.

All design and sketch credit goes to Supasorn, please check out his design but probably use this one if you need a simple quick solution for your Tarantula, Cheers!

This is a .dxf for a replacement y-axis carriage(to be water-jetted or laser-cut) for the tronxy X3 because I was sick of the warping of the acrylic bed. I imagine with some easy adaptation it could be used with other printers. I made it fairly universal, it can be used with 20/20 and 20/40 extrusion and also has spacing for 4 LM8UU bearing blocks. You can also modify it to fill in holes and add holes if you would like.

This is still a work in progress as I havent installed it yet(though everything lines up perfectly), but I will update it as I install and print pieces for it.

Update 3/30/2017:

Alright so I've used this on my printer for a few weeks, it works great. It is not without its caveats however...the slots for the wheels make it difficult to center and keep it tight, The slots and cutouts for the heated bed are kind of a pita, where the belt is supposed to be secured is a little too high in my setup, and pulls the belts awkwardly. Its well worth it if you can get it cutout for cheap though thats for sure! Otherwise I would check out the universal build plate from open builds.

For tronxy x3 users I would Highly suggest http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2215722
my wheel tensioner if you are going to stick with 2020 extrusion.

Noise & Vibration Dampeners for RepRap Prusa Mendel. Reduces noise, which is produced by the machine during printing, by more then 20dB.

Hello everybody, I've designed this noise dampeners to reduce the noise and vibration created by my RepRap Prusa Mendel. The main goles were to:

  • reduce the noise and vibration as much as possible

  • use the least material possible

  • accomodate variation of thickness of the printer feet.
    • For maximum nose & vibration reduction effect you need to meet following criteria: Material used: PLA Fill density: 100% Please let me know how it worked for you.

I've just put together and plan on adding bed-levelling (tramming) to my machine shortly. Are you using the A6 aluminum bed or is it possible to also have a glass top and still do auto-levelling?
comments.author: sculler1956

comments.text: I used a Voltage Divider in the signal wire of the sensor (R1=15k, R2=10K, being R2 the one connected to GND) and it showed around 4.9V, i didn't had major problems apart from setting up the sensor height but is just annoying not hard. For the bed, i'm using the stock aluminum bed with blue painters tape, glass would keep my sensor from detecting the bed (it's an inductive sensor), but a capacitive sensor should sense even in glass. I hope my answer help you, if i can do more for you, just ask. i can't promise anything but i'll do my best hahaha

description.text:
Motherfile and Tutorial, please visit:
http://www.portionstudio.com/model-bar/spiderman-head
File included:
-STP
-STL
-IGS
-OBJ
-Solidwork

Check out my remix of this: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2238228

A grip for the Nintendo Switch when used in portable mode.
Everything Nintendo makes seems to be for small hands, so this is too make it a bit more comfortable for everyone, whilst still allowing the JoyCons to charge.

Still very much a work in progress

The model is messy, but at 0.4mm, it irons out well.
I haven't printed the entire thing, only the grips, which seem to fit tight enough that I don't need to connect them with the middle piece.
I'm going to work on the ergonomics, I have been struggling with SolidWorks as I have no formal experience with it.

I had fun making this, it is only the first part of my overall vision, stay tuned! If you want to motivate me even more, feel free to drop me a tip! Totally optional, but It would definitely keep the fire burning :D

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.4mm

Infill:

18%

Optional

You may need to print the middle piece if the grips don't friction fit well enough for you as they did for me. I was planning on just using super glue or something.
I can't vouch for the entire assembly fitting perfectly.

If you print it up-right like I did, you may have to clean up the bottom where it may rough from the supports, like mine.
Due to the tight fitment, the finish on your JoyCons and Switch may start to wear away or get marked up.

comments.author: OtterNas3

comments.text: I know this is old, but it is very easy to find your own offsets if you have skynet3d Marlin. Load up arduino. Load the source for marlin. Plug into your anet.   Then I load pronter face. Home x and y. Don't worry about z. Just make sure it fairly close to bed. Using the manual control on pronter face, move the head to each corner of the bed. So when you do front right corner, look on the Anet's display. It will give you x's location. Then you punch that in the source. Once you have done that for all 4, disconnect pronterface. Then upload the firmware. Reconnect pronter face.  Home it, then run autolevel. Make sure it is going where you want. Then tweak the numbers in the firmware accordingly.

remixed_from.title: Companion cube double deckbox 2 x d20 dice

title: Magic The Gathering Deck Box Companion Cube - Commander size

description.text:
I've taken the companion cube deck box idea and made the following updates:

  1. Replaced the hearts with the MTG mana symbols. The top symbol is Phyrexian Mana.
  2. Expanded the deck box capacity to fit 100 double sleeved cards (at the expense of the tiny dice holder)
  3. Added a spacer at the bottom of the deck holder area to increase the height at which the cards sit, making it easier to remove them from the cube.

For those wondering why I chose the Phyrexian mana symbol instead of the obviously missing Red mana symbol - its because the Red mana symbol is boring, and kind of ugly.. I don't play much red, I guess.

I have uploaded a version of the lid with a thicker rim/border. I had to file it down just a bit, but found that it was much better at remaining closed than the original sized lid (from the non-remix part). I've included both. If you don't mind doing some post-processing, print the thicker border and scrape the edges down (safety first please!) until you are satisfied with the lid fitment.

I've added a size-comparison photo between this deckbox and the GOT style geared opening deckboxes. Those have a very very hard time holding 100 double-sleeved cards.

Added photos of the cube after finishing. Was going for a rusty prop from a sci-fi movie...

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

40%

Notes:

Actually using the FlashForge Dreamer, but thats no longer an option to select...

On my dreamer I had no problems printing with no supports except on the lid rim - where I had that first layer with no supports droop a bit. Adding supports on the main cube under the rim will help with final assembly. Having no supports did not affect the printing of the mana symbols.

Had no visible issues with lifting or warping. I use a heated bed, printing on a PEI sheet using the Purple glue stick between prints. A quick wipe with a damp paper towel (damp with water) to smear the leftover glue stick around works sometimes too.

Extruder Temp 245C
Bed Temp 120C. PEI (Polyetherimide) sheet taped (3M 468MP) to Aluminum bed.
Material: ABS (ebay, regular cheap filament)

Print time - Main Cube: 28 hrs.
Print time - Lid: 4 hrs

Hints for finishing the model

  • extrude some filament to obtain "thin" wires (for the cables)

  • use masking tape

description.text:
As i use a 12mm Inductive Sensor (LJ12A3-4-Z/BX) i had to mount it only on the lower mounting point as it is not long enough to mount it in upper and lower one.
The Sensor would not have been long enough to bring it down to sensing range in both mounts

So i decided to make the Mount plate a bit thicker for more stability.
It is not really needed as the Sensor doesnt move that much, and it is ok in only 1 mounting point.

print_settings.Notes:: For me, printing the lampholder ring takes about 10 minutes, the arms about 10 minutes each and the blanks take about an hour each if I impose a height field on them.

description.text:
The end user might duplicate the "Lightshade Blank" several times and add a height field image onto it in order to customise with a favoured design, pattern, or photo.

Parts you need to print:

  • 6 off the above blanks.
  • 3 off "Shadeholder Arm". These arms suspend the "blanks" from the "ring".
  • 1 off "Lampholder Ring". This is the part that screws onto the lamp and from which the rest of the design hangs.
  • 12 off "Rivets". these are the pieces which hold the blanks together. A file is included which comprises 15 of these in case some break or print badly.

In case the print doesn't work well, you might like to print the rivets in sets of 4, for example.

NB the "arms" require to be printed with support. I found that 10% is adequate on my Anet A8.

Included as one of the models is "Lightshade Model Complete". I do not recommend that you try to print it: it is included purely as an assembly guide.

I have included some photos which may contain images similar to something you may or may not have seen in real life. They do not claim to be representative of any particular toy or film. Nor do I claim to have created the images.

19-Mar-2017 UPDATE
I recommend printing the flat blanks first, then a small number of the rivets. Depending on your printer settings, you may find the rivets too small and loose in the holes. If this is turns out to be the case for many of you, I'll remodel them fatter.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm layers

Infill:

100% solid

Notes:

You might like to increase the resolution, but this will increase your print time and, given that the lampshade is 7ft up in the air, it's unlikely that anyone will look at it sufficiently closely to make a difference!

The arms require a 10% support and, unfortunately, that takes longer to print than the arms themselves.

For me, printing the lampholder ring takes about 10 minutes, the arms about 10 minutes each and the blanks take about an hour each if I impose a height field on them.

The rivets are pressed through the blanks to hold them together in a hexagon. 12 are required.

Note that each blank has three holes at the top. The centre holes are where the "arms" poke through. Note that there are only 3 arms. As such, every second blank will have an unused hole at the top centre.

This is based on the "bas relief" concept sometimes seen in ceramics, where the thicker the substrate, the less light passes through. Here, I have used 16 grey scales and imported the image as "Z" information.

This a Vape I have been building for a while now. Its well developed on V4 now and works very well.

You will need some battery terminals, the Top Box 75W board https://www.fasttech.com/p/4507200 and 510 connection.

I use 5 outer shells and 35% infill. Choose your own layer height and you need support. The buttons work best on 0.1 resolution. I use hot glue to stick the board in and dont solder the terminals in the box. it will melt the plastic.

There is a plain lid and a Die Antwoord logo lid you can choose.

Derivative of Walker's upload (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:105542). Love the scan, but there were a few places that needed some touching up. I used OpenSCAD to create a tub "insert" to fill in some gaps in the tub walls and to thicken them up slightly for scaled-down printing. Then I "aged" the tub using Meshlab, at the same time combining it with the original file. Next, I spent quite a bit of time in Blender removing some excess material (under the raised leg and right arm, plus a few scanning artifacts scattered around the model). Couldn't have done it without the original scan submitted by Walker!

description.text:
I designed a spool holder designed to be mounted on a wall or a workbench back and can hold numerous rolls of filament. You can print the rod to hold the spool or use a wooden or steel rod, whichever you have or can find cheaply.

If you're interested in the design process, check out my video: https://youtu.be/kk8dxeHFzG0

The objective of this project is help wheelchair users to Pick up objects from the ground and from high places. Project developed in Brazil.

ENGLISH:

Materials:

  • 80 cm of 1/2-inch PVC pipe
  • 2 rubber bands
  • 50 mm 5/16-inch aluminum bar
  • EVA sheet
  • 3 Bolts and nuts M3 x 25 mm
  • Neodymium magnet with 20 mm diameter x 3 mm height
  • multifilament fishing line
  • hot glue

Instructions:
Print the parts using support, raft and which 100% infill, except the lever, which can be done with 40%.
Fit the fixed part of the grip on the PVC pipe and drill the pipe with a 5/16 drill bit, as in the picture above. Do the same for the parts of the lever.

Cut the 5/16 aluminum bar in the following measurements:
2 x 115 mm
1 x 60 mm
1 x 36 mm
1 x 32 mm
1 x 14 mm
2 x 20 mm
1 x 30 mm

Attach the aluminum bars to the PVC pipe, tie the multifilament line to the bolt of the clamp and pass the line through the barrel.
Pass a little grease on the bushings and pulleys to reduce friction.
Cut 2 pieces of 16 x 60mm EVA and one piece of the size you think is best for the cable.
Then glue the pieces onto the grip and cable.
To make the hook tip with hot glue, print the molds to inject the parts. Spray some soap on the inside of the mold before injecting the hot glue, so that the glue does not stick to the mold.

PORTUGUÊS:

Materiais:

  • 80 cm de Cano de PVC 20 mm
  • 45 cm de Barra redonda de alumínio 5/16 polegadas de diâmetro
  • 2 Elásticos de “dinheiro”
  • 1 m de Linha multifilamento 45 lbs
  • imã de neodímio com 20mm de diâmetro e 3mm de espessura
  • 3 Parafusos com 4mm de diâmetro e 25 mm de comprimento
  • Folha de EVA
  • cola quente

Instruções:
Imprima as peças utilizando suporte, raft e com 100% de enchimento, exceto o manete, que pode ser impresso com 40% de enchimento.
Encaixe a parte fixa da pinça na ponta do cano de PVC, em seguida fure o cano com uma broca de 8mm, como nas fotos acima. Faça a mesma coisa para as peças do manete.

Corte a barra de alumínio 5/16 nas seguintes medidas:
2 x 115 mm
1 x 60 mm
1 x 36 mm
1 x 32 mm
1 x 14 mm
2 x 20 mm
1 x 30 mm

Encaixe as barras de alumínio no cano de PVC, amarre a ponta da linha multifilamento no parafuso da pinça e passe-a por dentro do cano.
Passe um pouco de graxa nas buchas e polias para reduzir o atrito.
Corte 2 pedaços de 16 x 60 mm da folha de EVA e um pedaço do tamanho que achar melhor para colar no cabo. Em seguida cole os pedaços de EVA na pinça e no cabo com cola quente.
Para fazer a ponta do gancho com cola quente, imprima os moldes para injetar as peças. Passe um pouco de sabão na parte interna do molde antes de injetar a cola quente, para que a cola não grude no molde.

description.text:
Housing for Lifecam HD-3000

A slim camera housing that fits into the Qidi Avatar IV, FlashForge Creator and similar printers. It is looking down to the build plate, tilted down by 9°.

Additional requirements:

  • Microsoft Lifecam HD-3000
  • OctoPrint with a free USB port

The original housing of the Lifecam HD-3000 will be removed and destroyed, the four screws will be re-used.

Opening the original case (see picture):

  1. Unlock the two screws at the back, on the left and right side of the rubber grip.
  2. Take the case apart, but pulling forward at the bottom (there are three notches at the top)
  3. Unlock the two screws that hold the PCB
  4. Pull the microphone out of it's tight-fit plastic
  5. Pull the silver metal spring holding the black metal pin
  6. Remove the black metal pin holding the rubber grip
  7. Remove the rubber grip
  8. Use pliers to cut the back side and remove the USB cable
  9. Use pliers to remove all the hard plastic glued to the USB cable

Rebuilding with the new case:

  1. Put the PCB into the printed base, and lock it with two screws (there's a cable exit on one side and a space for the microphone on the other side)
  2. Put the top on the case and lock it from the back with two screws
  3. Move the case inside the printer and push up the mounts up in-between the two metal sheets of the printer (there's a screw at the center of the printer so it's easier if you do one mount first away from the center and then the second mount diagonally)
  4. Put the cable up and out through a space between the printer housing and the acrylic top.
  5. Plug the USB into your OctoPrint and enjoy

Qidi Avatar IV

See the script case.lua for how it's modeled.

title: Low Friction Spool Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Low Friction Spool Holder (For Trinus Enclosure)

In order to build this thing you'll need two 6203 ball bearings (40x12mm 17mm Hole)
In its current form changing a spool can be a bit difficult as it is not possible to stop the tube from spinning while fastening the nut. I'm still working on a V2.

Spool Size: Please note that only spools with a larger inner diameter than 46mm will fit!

Threads

If you have a hard time screwing everything together, take a bit of sandpaper and sand them flush. And be sure to remove any strings inside the threads. Mine printed flawlessly and screwed without any binding.

No Enclosure

I'm also working on a direct adapter for this tool. So if you don't have the enclosure right now and wan't to use this this – there is something on the way.

Printer:

Kodama Trinus 3D

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Please note that you'll need support for the Outer-Tube.stl and End-Cap.stl as they have a 90° overhang. Everything else prints fine without support.

Also be sure to print at 0.1mm layer height. The tolerances of the threads are low and if you increase the layer height too much they wont work!

comments.text: This thing is amazing! Great work! Fits like a dream on my Trinus thank you!

title: Bulb Holder for AOK 3-in-1 LiPo Battery Discharger

description.text:
This is a simple bulb holder for the AOK 3-in-1 150W LiPo/LiFe Battery Discharger.

The discharger uses three 50W bulbs to discharge a battery, and in use the bulbs get hot. The holder simply provides a safe way to keep the bulbs off the surface the discharger is being used on.

In case anyone is wondering, the bulbs supplied seem to be G5.3 24V 50W. The bulb holders are universal and will also accept GY6.35 24V 50W bulbs as well.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Probably best printed in ABS, as the bulbs give off a fair bit of heat.
The bulb holders should be a tight fit and not require screws, but small screws could be added to secure the holders in if needed.

author: meson03

description.text:
An Earbud Holder to keep your earbud cables neat and tangle free, designed to fit all sizes and styles of in-the-ear earbuds including those with control modules as used on the iPhone.
For an EarPod holder designed for the newer Apple EarPods, go to http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:598228 and for a holder designed for the older Apple Earbuds, go to http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13678.

Drop the earbuds in the recesses and start wrapping the cable by bringing it down and under the lip to the right, then up again, catching it in the right slot, then left and over the buds and down through the left slot. Hold the spooler and wrap the cable until the jack is close to the farthest hole it will reach. If it won't quite reach, unspool about a half turn, insert the jack, then roll the loose cable over the bottom lip, using one of the slots if it won't fit over the whole spool.  
For earbuds with a control module on the cord, start wrapping the cable by bringing it down and under the lip to the left and use the bottom slot to bring the module to the rear and across, then back through the opposite bottom slot to continue wrapping the cord. (See the photo.)

comments.text: I believe the angle made by the plug is dangerous for that bit of cable: a set of 45 degrees angled holes for the plug should still provide enough friction to hold and reduce the stress on the last cord bit.

title: Wrench Ratchet with rotating shift and compression spring

description.text:
This is a working Wrench ratchet tool, this is the first thing i made on my new Duplicator 4. All models drawn in Solidworks. Extra: Socket Wrench pipe: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:219190
http://youtu.be/HacHFjdPr9A

Everything is made inn ABS, also compression spring
Parts are glued together with ABS soup. The compression of the spring is quite good. Raft is only used for the smallest parts like spring and pin. Use ABS soup to make parts stick to glass plate, this works very well. I`m new so i use Makerware for now, have tried ReplicatorG but for me is Makerware fastest and easiest.
Included orginal base house.stl but this part needs support for printing
To modify print setting in Makerware i recommend PROFTWEAK from Nothinglabs (http://nothinglabs.blogspot.no/2013/09/introducing-proftweak-makerware-profile.html)

title: Fairly Beefy Control Horns (Designed for M3 Threads)

description.text:
A fairly strong control horn for use on remote controlled airplanes. These are designed to be sturdy and withstand fairly large loads.
They're also designed around M3 screws: The holes in the base plate are 2.5mm in diameter to take an M3 thread. The holes on the vertical arm are 3mm in diameter to take an M3 linkage stopper.

Printing free-standing holes and the need for support Allows for experimentation of printing with supports, and serves as a foundation for exploration on how 3D prints can be optimized to accommodate machine screws/threads.

Materials: -Your choice of printing filament.
-M3 Screws
-M3 linkage stoppers
-M3 pushrods

title: Three lead screws and one nema 17 motor remix for C/D/J-bot

description.text:
A solution for using three 8mm lead screws on your bot using only one nema motor. Making your bed more solid and get rid of the sag. Im also using 40 teeth pulley on rods and 20 teeth on motor to get 2:1 ratio. Doubles the steps_per_mm

GT2 belt loop 6mm wide and 1524mm long. If having problem different tension between rods add another pin made of M5x25mm screw with 2 flange ball bearings. Im using 5x13x4mm Mini F695ZZ bearings.

The metal mount for lead screw:
http://www.ebay.com/itm/231452345160?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

Recommend using this mod with:
3-wheeled Z guide (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1802733) on all four corners like on the J-bot (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1721957) for rock solid result.

The backlash nuts I'm using: http://ooznest.co.uk/ACME-Anti-Backlash-Nut
Modded bracket: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1776493

Nema17 mount used in pic: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1488174

Example picture: Side of green 60x60 box after update. Zero imperfections or z-wobble :D

Benefits explained in this video(not made by me): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1OLWSarvgDM

author: Aero3D

title: Anet A8 Print Head Micrometer Height Adjuster

description.text:
This is a Anet A8 Micrometer height adjuster for the print head .The back half fits directly onto the 3 linear bearing blocks the same as the original aluminium bracket , & uses all original screws for mounting . An adjustable dovetail wedge plate slides into the rear mount & the original Print head/extruder screw directly to this plate using 3mm x 10mm self tapping screws . An Inductive sensor mount is also provided , in 12mm & 18mm sizes to mount a sensor .
A piece of 8mm x 1mm fine pitch threaded rod ( or 5/16 UNF can be used too) x 140mm long & 3 nuts are needed for the variable height adjuster .A thumb wheel with 10 graduated l markings is used to adjust the height . This gives a resolution of 0.1mm ( 0.004") per graduation & allows the head 12mm of variable height adjustment .A compression spring 25mm long x 10mm is used to Take all backlash out of the design , as well stop any vibrations
Adjustments can be made while the machine is printing , so if a brim layer appears to be slightly too high or low , it can be adjusted immediately with out having to stop printing or adjust the control panel .

Adjustments are completely independent of all electronics, sensors & home switches etc, So once an adjustment has been made it will remain constant for all further prints .

Whilst there are electronic adjustments & updated firmware available , & the sensor upgrade has drastically improved Z axis calibration , i still find this device particularly useful to make fine & accurate adjustments quickly on the go.

The 2 dovetail wedge parts should be a neat , almost a little tight , so there is no movement or vibration between the 2 parts .
If they are too tight , just pear some plastic away with a sharp knife until the fit is correct .

You will loose 20mm of Y axis with the additional thickness of the mount , but you can get most of that back by spacing the Y axis home micro switch forward as there is some room left on the Y axis sliders ,You an also change the offsets in the arduino firmware if your confident editing arduino code. Just make sure you measure everything & re-calibrate your slicer software for your maximum Y travel & test that you don't exceed axis travel .

You will also need some M3 x 40mm Countersunk screws & nuts for the sensor mount & the belt mounting pins .

Update :(April 8 2017) Just added a mount to fit a Bowden E3D -V6 Extruder head that screws directly to the Front Slider Mount at (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2236009)

Update: 12/4/2017 added a sensor mount for the Tronix XY08n sensor

Update : 8/5/2017 Just added a sensor mount for a 30mm diamater proximity sensor. Its ugly but it has a 15mm Sensing range , so it is much better & has much more clearance when using a glass table .

print_settings.Notes:: 2-perimiters recommended. Some slicers may have problems with the "spool 1" file - check the g-code preview to make sure it figures it out.

description.text:
This is a small spool for the sample filaments you probably have lying all over the place. The files are divided into halves for later assembly. There are 2 versions:

  • "szpula 1" and "szpula 2" - a smaller version, 44mm hole, ~20mm wide for tiny samples. The halves are a bit loose and require some glue to stick together.
  • "szpulaD1" and "szpulaD2" - a bit bigger version, ~50mm hole, ~30mm wide. This one is tighter, so the halves should jam together on their own.

Each half weights from 11-13 grams (PLA) so it doesn't consume too much material.

I reccomend printing it with a double perimeter and at least 15% infill, but you can feel free to experiment with it (I've printed the big one with a single perimeter and it works just fine.

The spools have a tiny 2mm slit to catch the end of the filament when you put it on the roll (although the slit in the big version doesn't work too well so you will probably need to drill a 1.75mm hole somewhere - maybe I will modify the files to fix it someday... maybe).
Enjoy. :)

title: PS Vita Thumbstick Extender and Widener

description.text:
These two thumbstick extensions will really help your aim game. After printing I suggest to buy Rubber Coating spray to get that authentic thumbstick feel. You can find it here http://www.homedepot.com/p/Performix-Brand-11-oz-Plasti-Dip-Black-Rubber-Coating-Spray-11203-6/100131010#
Has really helped my aim, especially during PS4 remote play and first person shooters. Note: Will work with both the original PS Vita 1000 as well as the the new PS Vita Slim 2000

I made this model by taking the PS3's thumbstick extender and scaling it down to Vita size. After tweaking many of the parts so that it would not feel awkward I went to Home Depot and bought this:
http://www.homedepot.com/p/Performix-Brand-11-oz-Plasti-Dip-Black-Rubber-Coating-Spray-11203-6/100131010# After spraying this on for about three layers, the thumbstick extensions felt and looked authentic and made the gameplay experience much better.

description.text: The latch holding the hazard triangle compartment closed on my 2002 Audi Avant broke a few years ago. Armed with a 3D printer I sought to rectify the situation. After three iterations, this is my solution which includes three parts.

Printer:

QIDI Pro

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%, 65%

Notes:

Higher infill will result in a stronger latch, especially for the shaft (recommended). If you don't use supports, there is some bridging which if not clean will ruin the print.

Assembly

The shaft without the hole is pressed into the operator. This is a press fit, but may require a touch of glue to ensure it's secure. The two parts were assembled in place with a #4 screw. The hole in the shaft is undersized to allow for flexibility in different screw sizes and was drilled out for the #4 wood screw I used.
Designed in Solidworks

description.text:
***Update 21/03/17 All the templates have been checked for errors, fixed and re-uploaded. Note that only the 2 and 3 Large Banks are still broken. If anyone can print these let me know and I'll fix them for you.

The next evolution to the X-wing Casual Assist templates are here - The Swoosh series templates!

Using the standard templates you have to place it, move the ship back and away a bit before placing it on the other end. It just doesn't make you feel like the ship is going "swoosh"!

With these templates, place it behind the ship and "swoosh" it along to the end of the template. It's just like flying a ship. No back tracking, lifting or sideways moving required (unless you need to dodge other ships). Nothing can be more fun or satisfying*

They also do a similar job to the side turn templates released previously.

**Note: A larger then 200mm x 200mm print area is required to print some of these templates.

Usage:
Select the template that matches the base of your ship (small or large) and the manoeuvre it is doing (1/2/3 bank/turn/straight). Place one end in the nubs behind the ship and then simply push the ship along forwards along the template to the nubs at the other end. Simple and Swooshie!

Included:

  • Small Ship 1,2 and 3 turn swooshes

  • Small Ship 1,2 and 3 bank swooshes (3 may require rotation to fit into print area)

  • Large Ship 1,2 and 3 bank swooshes (1 will require rotation, 2 & 3 are still broken.)

  • Large Ship 1,2 and 3 turn swooshes (work great!)

  • Small Ship 1,2,3,4 and 5 straight swoosh (3,4 and 5 may not fit 200 x 200 print area)

  • Small Ship 1/2/3 combo straight swoosh (may not fit 200 x 200 print area)

  • Large Ship 1/2 combo straight swoosh (the rest will not fit most people's printers)
  • Small & Large Ship BYO template swoosh adaptor (print x2 of each for maximum swoosh!)

For the BYO template, you need to print one of each end for both large and small based ships. Choose the template for the ship base, position the larger template at the rear of the ship, place the choosen standard template (straight, bank or turn should all work) and place the smaller template at the other end. Swoosh your ship forward and your done.

Feed back mostly appreciated! Please leave a comment.

*fun and/or satisfaction may vary

title: HandOfCronus216b - The integrated pan and slide camera system
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I've made a system that can accurately move a digital camera along a predetermined path, creating great time lapse and movie recordings. Although the concept isn't new, the approach is. And this was to include all of these features in one compact module whilst keeping the rails as a simple passive component. This in turns makes the system more easy to transport and set up while allowing it to be as versatile as most others. This system can run at speeds suitable for both movie recording and time lapse photography, giving pan motion and/or slide motion shooting, both with one of the rails from the "SmartRail"-system or on a regular tripod.

This project is also featured in the Arduino Blog, see the link bellow:
http://www.arduino.org/blog/handofcronus216b-project

Inspiration

The photographing community have seen a lot of systems to assist in the creation of time lapse and movie recordings, but all of them share the same problems. They are big, they are expensive, and they demand a special motorized rail system.

So I set out to create an unique and versatile pan and slide camera system. A rugged system with independence and compactness that could be fitted to any kind of rail. It can be short, long or even concave, whichever is needed but most importantly, a rail that is easy to make. Or if only the pan motion feature is needed, it can easily be mounted on a tripod with its Quick-mounts that fits all standard cameras and tripods.

Function

This system was in the beginning only meant to be used for time laps photography, but it was soon extended for use in movie recordings as well. This is selected via knobs on the front panel that controls settings as run speed, direction, locking or disabling of the steppers. And all of this information is then fed to the operator by the OLED displays easy-to-use graphic interface, which also includes hints for camera setup. The module is powered by a regular li-ion battery accessible from the outside, and charging can be done just like a phone, with its built-in USB charger.

This "Thing" is mainly meant as an inspiration for those wanting to design and build there own camera pan and slide system. This is because many of the components that I've used is not readily available, but with that said, all of the component that I designed and printed can be downloaded and so also a model of the aluminum chassis.

The Arduino code that I developed for the ATmega2560 processor that controls the module can be found under "Files" and it requires the following Arduino libraries: Adafruit_SH1106, Adafruit_GFX and AccelStepper.

Some of the components used are: A IIC controlled 1.3" OLED display, two A4988 drivers with low profile 3D printer steppers, a 18650 Li-ion battery with holder and USB-charging circuit, two binary coded hexadecimal rotary switches, a Meduino Mega2560 R3 Pro Mini, etc.

Feel free to post you prints!

title: GPS Mount - TomTom XXL 540 TM
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This dashboard mount replaces the TomTom XXL 540 TM car windshield mount. I made it because the suction cup on my mount no longer works.
I designed it in SolidWorks, and printed it on a Stratasys Fortus 400mc using ABS-M30.

1) Print both STL files on a 3D printer.
2) Fasten the stand and ring mount together at the desired tilt with an M3x22 socket head cap screw and M3 nut.
3) Apply velcro tape to the bottom of your stand and to your car dashboard.

description.text:
I printed the original for my Lulzbot TAZ 5 and it works great. Made this extension to the camera mount so I could get my camera further away from the print bed.

Before and After picture are screenshots from OctoPrint from the camera before and after extension was installed.

NOTE if you want the extension shorter just cut it in your slicer. If you want it longer drop me a note and I can extend it.

https://youtu.be/SftQWD4XOis

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Tinkercad

https://www.tinkercad.com/things/dvqRzf9WhK5-camera-mount-extension-for-raspberry-pi-case/

comments.text: Any strength problems due to the print orientation of the main rod? Wouldn't this part be stronger if printed horizontally? I suppose the pi cam is pretty light so I doubt there's any stress, just curious if anyone has had issues.
comments.author: Brandito

comments.text: I haven't had any problems with strength.  The one problem I had was in using this and printing with my enclosure closed the temps got high enough to loosen the PLA joints.  I used a zip strip to put pressure on the ball join clamps, but haven't put the extension back on yet.  I think I need to print in ABS, but I'm lazy and haven't done it yet :)
comments.author: Brandito

comments.text: Print in something other than PLA if you have an enclosure.  Printed some ABS for the first time in a long while today and the ball joints are super loose now.

author: Gbarnett374

description.text:
This effector was designed to simplify hotend replacement.

I use both Volcano and Cyclops hotends. This hotends has completely different mounting technique and require whole effector replacement for Kossel printers family.
Most 3d-printed effectors has no secure nut pocket, nuts tends to fall out and and get lost, process is tricky and fiddly due most people have only two hands.

This effector has different kind of pockets to hold nuts tight and secure.

Ball joint holes may need to be drilled (3mm) before lock nuts into their pockets.

Please note that effector radius is 22mm.
Lamp shade for a ceiling mounted light. Holes to allow air flow. Best used with LED lights, as heat will be an issue with incandescent.

Screw Caps

These caps press on the head of Socket Head Cap Screws. There are three designs; knurled, lobed, and winged for either a M3 or M4 screw. Use a hammer, c-clamp, vice, or arbor press to press the caps on the head of the screw. The press needs to be between .005-.01" to work properly. Print one out and test it before you print out a bunch of them. If the fit is not correct scale the .stl slightly in your slicer to correct it.

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

comments.text: Sorry those are all for Socket head screws.  I'm pretty sure you can find hex head versions if you search for them. They will be a 2 piece design as I don't think a press on design would work very well with a hex head.  These work because socket heads are round and have ridges on the OD that keep them from spinning once pressed on.

description.text:
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/1mjMt2Dkx3r

I modified this original design from Elzariant. I found that the original nozzle outlets were blowing to much on my hot end cooling it off so I extended it a bit as well as making the hole that fits around the 40mm fan smaller. More of a close fit. I also embedded the spider web across the entire front face.
